clinical_study.brief_title: Transcutaneous Oxygen Pressure of the Injured Ankle as Predictor of Postoperative Cutaneous Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Transcutaneous Oxygen Pressure of the Injured Ankle as Predictor of Postoperative Cutaneous Pain

brief_summary.textblock: This monocentric prospective observational pilot study aims to investigate if the measurement of TcPO2 can be used as a predictor of postoperative cutaneous pain in patients with ankle surgery.

detailed_description.textblock:
This prospective observational study aims to determine the limit of TcPO2 predictive of postoperative cutaneous pain in patients with ankle trauma.
A TcPO2 measurement will be performed preoperatively at the patient's arrival in the emergency room, then every day after the operation for 3 days and finally at the follow-up visits at 3 and 6 weeks.
The cutaneous pain is evaluated by a PSAS self-questionnaire (completed by the patient) and an OSAS questionnaire (completed by the surgeon). These grids evaluate the tolerance and cicatricial quality in the medium and long term by the operator and the patient.

primary_outcome.measure: Presence of postoperative skin pain within 3 months postoperatively

secondary_outcome.measure: Preoperative TcPO2 on the injured ankle and contralateral ankle
secondary_outcome.description: compare TcPO2 values between healthy ankle and traumatized ankle

secondary_outcome.measure: Preoperative and postoperative day 1 TcPO2 on the injured ankle
secondary_outcome.description: Compare TcPO2 values before and after surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Rates of postoperative complications related to S12 surgery and TcPO2 measurements
secondary_outcome.description: Measure surgical complications based on TcPo2 measurements

secondary_outcome.measure: Surgical revision rate at S12 and TcPO2 measurements
secondary_outcome.description: Measure the number of surgical revisions based on TcPo2 measurements

secondary_outcome.measure: Preoperative and postoperative day 1 TcPO2 on the injured ankle and type of fracture
secondary_outcome.description: Describe the TcPO2 measurements according to the type of fracture

secondary_outcome.measure: Preoperative and postoperative day 1 TcPO2 on the injured ankle and comorbidities such as pulmonary pathologies, microangiopathy, vascular pathologies, history of trauma
secondary_outcome.description: Describe the measures of TcPO2 according to comorbidities

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient scar assessment scale (PSAS grid) at S6 and S12
secondary_outcome.description: Describe the type of skin pain according to TcPO2 measurement The PSAS observation scale consists of 7 questions for the patient concerning pain, itching, colour, suppleness, thickness, appearance and a general opinion on the scar. Each parameter is rated on a scale from 1 (best score) to 10 (worst score). The sum of the 7 parameters gives the total score (minimum value = 7 ; maximum value = 70).

Each parameter is rated on a scale from 1 (best score) to 10 (worst score). The sum of the 7 parameters gives the total score (minimum value = 7 ; maximum value = 70).

secondary_outcome.measure: OSAS Scale (observer scars assessment scale) at S6 and S12
secondary_outcome.description: Measure the quality of healing The OSAS observation scale consists of seven parameters (vascularization, pigmentation, thickness, relief, plasticity, surface and a global evaluation). Each parameter is rated on a scale ranging from 1 ("like normal skin") to 10 ("the worst scar imaginable"). The sum of the 7 parameters gives the observer's total score (minimum value = 7 ; maximum value = 70).

study_pop.textblock: The population studied concerns all adult patients suffering from ankle trauma requiring surgical management, it is heterogeneous, concerns all ages, regardless of co-morbidities. Minor patients and patients unable to give their consent will not be included.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with surgery of ankle trauma
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient who does not agree to participate
- Patient unable to express agreement (ex: unconscious)
- Minor patient
- Major patient under tutorship or curatorship
